HE spirit shown by the foot-ball team at the B. M. C. game was true
Hopkins spirit; and the same spirit was evident in most of the men
who turned out to root for the team. The trouble is that only a few
came
to the game and the rooting was weak, as compared with that
V

of
the
B. M. C. Not over fifty men showed up in the cheering secV.

There is not the slightest reason why the Johns Hopkins foot-ball
V

of other colleges. There is absolutely no excuse why every
V V V
undergraduate should not come to every game from now on. We
have a field. We have a team. We can have rooters, if they will come out. During the
remainder of the season there are many important games to be played, and it seems to us that
a team which put up as manly a fight as did ours on the 26th deserves at least the hearty and
willing support of every member of the University. At the present writing the game with
Mt. Washington is to be played within a few hours. We trust that the showing made by the
rooters will compare in spirit with that which will certainly be made by our team. When this
issue of the NEWS-LETTER appears, the Delaware game will be on hand. Everybody simply
must come out and root;—and root hard.
N another page of this issue we print a short notice of the Cotillon
Club which is in a measure official since it comes from a member of
the committee. We beg leave to say that the NEWS-LETTER did not
think "that the Board of Governors of the Cotillon Club was idle."
The decision to "limit the number of the Board to twelve men, as
the Board was getting too large," fits in fairly well with our views
as expressed two weeks ago. Altogether the arrangements of the
Board for the coming season are satisfactory. The Cotillon Club, as
every other interest at the University, should have our hearty support. The dances are on Friday night, so hard-worked students can
not plead lessons as an excuse for not coming. Last year all these dances were very delightful and the series this year promises to be equally so.

BALLAD OF THE LADY MARGARET AND HER ROBBER-LOVER.
'T was a cold night of December and the wind was whistling drear,
The robber-band was gathered round the camp-fire flashing clear;
The robber-band was crouching, but their haughty chief stood high,
And he spoke to his fellow bandits—
Ferocious bloody bandits!
His burly, brother bandits under the star-lit sky.
II
"Now is the time to do it"—he raised his arm and said—
'For the young lord's off a'wooing and the old lord's lying dead,
The young lord courts his lady nor knows his father's fall,
And his sister Lady Margaret—
The radiant Lady Margaret—
The matchless, priceless Margaret is alone by her father's pall.

"Now is the time, my comrades, I've woo'd her long in vain,
But soft words now are over—I'll not be scorned again !
With twenty sturdy fellows and this good sword at my side
I'll seize the Lady Margaret—
The fair, disdainful Margaret—
And take my Lady Margaret to be my forest bride,"

•••

•

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

IV.
Around about the fire were twenty men or-more,
And all their faces brightened—they loved adventure sore!
Yes, all the bandits smiled with glee at what their chief had planned,
Save of the number two men—
Of all that number two men
Only were good and true men in all that robber-band.
V.
The first of these had long a grudge against the robber-chief
And long had sworn, when time would serve, he'd cause him mickle grief;
The other was a younger man as unlike as could be,
For he loved the Lady Margaret—
The high, disdainful Margaret—
And none to Lady Margaret was half so true as he.
VI.
So when the robber-band at last had laid them all to rest—
When the plans were now discarded—and the laughter and the jest—
When o'er their heads the moon-light made the night almost as day;
One rose among the sleepers—
Crawled slowly from the sleepers—
Then left behind the sleepers—and spurred his horse away.
VII.
And then a little later, when a cloud came o'er the mcion,
(The moon was paling rapidly, the dawn was coming soon,)
Another figure rose among the sleepers on the ground,
And crept to where his horse stood,
His pride, his gallant horse stood,
The finest horse in camp stood—and still the band slept sound !

VIII.
"Ah, lord, this is no time for love—go not to court to-day,
For thy father lies full stark and still at his castle far away—
Thy sister Margaret weeps nor knows she is in peril sore,
For the robber-bandits come to-night—
Creeping quietly on to-night—
And will take the lady away to-night; she will be seen no more.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

5

X
It was the soft full mid-night—the moon was overhead—
Within the castle banquet hall they watched the noble dead.
And Margaret wept softly when into the castle hall
Clattered her brother the young lord—
Dank with sweat was the young lord,
Grimed with dust was the young lord—and fear came on them all.
XI
Behind him were his archers—"Ye know Our places right,
Get ye at once to the windows—whomever ye see to-night
Creeping, running or walking—turn he his face or his back,
Stop not to think for a moment,
Hesitate not for a moment,
But take good aim for a moment and shoot him down in his track.
•
•
•
XII.
"God grant I may reach her and save her !"—'Twas the robber-lover who prayed,
And his breath came faster and harder, but he stopped not a moment nor staid.
His horse he had left dead behind him—he was nearing the castle wall,
And fifty eyes were before him—
Watching eagerly for him—
Death itself was before him—aimed from the banquet-hall.
XIII.
He came but to warn her of danger—but how were the archers to know?
And they saw him creep in the moon-light in the castle-court below;
A moment they stopped—fifty arrows fleet from their long-bows sped,
And the hero stood but a moment,
Staggered and reeled for a moment,
Then fell in his tracks in a moment—and lay there stark and dead.
XIV.
The lady was saved without him—but in the dark of the earliest morning,
His cold and lifeless body was for the robbers a warning;
For the archers thought, when they slew him, the danger was overpassed.
In life his courage was useless,
His loving courage was useless;
But in death it was not useless—and his story deserves to last!

TALK II—Marlowe, Jonson and Some Nineteenth Century Poets.

Swinburne, I believe, and this morning I have
been looking over his sonnets on the English
Dramatic Poets of the time of Elizabeth and
James. They are not only fine poetry, but
fairly accurate, if a little extravagant, criticisru
as well. The sonnet on Webster is magnificent, as are the opening lines of that on Marlows:

the Elizabethans, and, where five hundred
people have read "Man and Superman," and
"Mrs. Warren's Profession," barely one

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Reader—"Lay thy bow"
The Critic—Yes, that's it,—
"Lay thy bow of pearl apart,
And thy silver shining quiver;
Give unto the flying hart
Space to breathe, how short soever.
Thou that mak'st a day of night
Goddess excellently bright."

After reading that would not any one exclaim: "0 rare Ben Jonson !" And, by the
way, it is a curious fact that no one has even
noted in print—at least, to my knowledge—
the mistake in this famous inscription. I
noticed myself in Westminster Abbey the
name is spelt "Johnson."
The Reader—Indeed. It's strange no one
has called attention to it. Speaking just now
of "Dr. Faustus" reminds me that Stephen
Phillips is writing a tragedy on the subject.
The Critic—Yes,I have heard so, and I don't
know whether anxiety or pleasure predominates in my feelings as I look forward to its
publication. It is really a fearful undertaking,
but I believe the author of "Paola and Francesca" can make a fine "stage play" clothed
upon with exquisite verse from the material
which resulted in Marlowe's hands in a mingling of radiance and rubbish, and in Goethe's
in an enormous philosophical poem. At all
events, the comparison between the work of
the two British poets will be of interest. Some
year or so ago I was interested in the resemblance between Mr. Phillip's "Nero" and the
anonymous Jacobean play of the same name.
Phillips does not suffer in comparison, though
"Nero" is certainly the poorest of his dramas.
However, it contains much good verse, such as
the description of Poppaza
"Yet hath none fairer strayed into the world,
Nor wandered in more witchery through the air;
Since she who drew the keels of Greece
After her over the Ionian foam."

No pre-Keatsian poet could have written
that. And yet it is not imitation, but an evidence of the poet's natural lineage from the
master.
The Reader—And what a master! Surely,
there is no poem like "The Nightingale" in the
language.
The Critic—No; to use a slang expression,
it and the "Grecian Urn" are in a class by
themselves. There is a white heat of imagination in "The Nightingale."

-

7

"Give to the nightingale her shady woods,
A privacy of glorious light is thine!"

Thus Wordsworth addresses the skylark,
and yet the "se f-same song" of the nightingale,
"Found a path
Through the . sad heart of Ruth when, sick for home,
She stood in tears amidst the alien corn,
The same that ofttimes bath
Charmed magic casements opening on the foam
Of perilous seas in fairy lands forlorn."

The imagination of this is delicious.
The Reader—But Phillips has almost as
much claim to Tennyson as his master as to
Keats.
The Crtic —Yes; "Marpessa," which is
probably his most widely known poem, does
resemble Tennyson's classic studies, more in
subject and treatment, however, than in actual
form. The priceless "faint Homeric echoes"
are not there. In its places there is verse less
grand, though not less beautiful; less lofty,
but just as pure.
"Thy voice is like to music heard in birth,
Some spirit lute touched on a spirit sea ;
Thy face remembered is from other worlds,
it has been died for, though T know not when;
It has been sung of, though I know not where,
It has the strangeness of the luring west,
And of sad sea horizons ; beside thee
I am aware of other times and lands,
Of births far back, of lives in many stars,
0 beauty, lone, and like a candle clear
In this dark country of the world!"

The Reader—You quoted a couple of lines
from Wordsworth awhile ago—from the marvelous lines to a skylark. I wish I appreciated
Wordsworth more. I feel as if a certain and
necessary catholicity of taste in matters literary was wanting in me because I find "The
Excursion" very, very dull.
The Critic—I suppose I should be ashamed
of myself, but I fear I agree with you. I love
Wordsworth, but I love him mainly for half
a dozen sonnets and three or four perfect
poems. No less a critic than Matthew Arnold
has said that "Laodamia" and the "Intimations of Immortality" did not represent his
best work. Doubtless, Arnold was right. He
ought to know. But I think they are incomparably his greatest poems. Arnold criticises
a certain artificiality in "Laodamia" and the
declamatory style of the "Immortal Ode," as

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Dr. Furness has called it. Maybe he is
right. Certainly the last verse of the
classic poem — that describing how the
trees withered when they were tall enough to
sec the "topless towers of Ilium"—is artificial,
but in some stanzas, notably two, all trace of
artificiality is lost. I say "notably two." I
mean, of course:
"He spake of love, such love as spirits feel,
In worlds whose course is equable and pure;
No cares to heat away, no strifes to heal,
The past unsighed for and the future sure.
Spake as a witness of a second birth,
For all that is most perfect upon earth.
For all that is most beauteous imagined there
In happier beauty, more pellucid streams
An ampler ether, a diviner air,
And fields invested with purpureal gleams
Climes which the sun who sheds the brightest day
Earth knows, is all unworthy to survey."

As you probably know, the poet altered the
last two lines of the stanzas first quoted to :
"Spake of heroic arts in graver mood,
Revived, with finer harmony pursued."

The alteration is lamentable.
As for the great "Ode," it may tend a trifle
to declamation at times, but at its best it is
glorious.
"Not in entire forgetfulness,
Nor yet in utter nakedness,
But trailing clouds of glory do we come,
From God, who is our home."

The Reader—To go back again, that same
quotation you made from Wordsworth's
"Skylark" reminds me of one of my favorite
poems—Shelly's ode to the same "blithe spirit."
The Critic—Ali, what a genius that man
was!
"In the golden lightning
Of the sunken sun,
O'er which clouds are brightening,
Thou (lost float and run,
Like an unbodied joy whose race has just
begun."

George Meredith has also written a poem on
a Skylark. But, for the wonder of his novels, I
have sometimes thought it were a pity he had
not given his life to poetry. I do not care for
his later verse, but "Love in the Valley," with
its fresh, perfumed morning beauty, is graceful and delicate and worthy of the author of
the two chapters on Richard's early love for
Lucy, in "Feverel":

"She whom I love is hard to catch and conquer;
Hard, but 0 the glory of the winning were she won."

Might not those lines be the guiding motto
of many a man ?
Of a very different sort is "Modern Love."
It has always been too sad, too morbid, for
my taste, save one sonnet only—that of the
momentary reconciliation of husband and wife
by the "twilight wave," under the flight of the
swallows:
"Love, that had robbed us of immortal things,
. This little moment mercifully gave,
And still I see across the twilight wave
The swan sail with her young beneath her wings."

MUSICAL CLUBS.
At the meeting of the Glee Club last week
the leader proposed a new plan, which was accordingly adopted. Although it is something
entirely new for Hopkins, it has been carried
out with great success by several other colleges. Their plan is this: Instead of coming
out in the same old way, first the Glee Club
and then the Mandolin Club, both of the clubs
will be seated on the stage during the entire
performance. There will be an opening
chorus, after which the end men will get off
a few good jokes, and the program will be
continued in more or less the usual manner.
There will be selections by the Mandolin Club
and by the Glee Club. The selections by the
(flee Club will be sung in parts, as usual, but
hesides these there will be several solos of popular songs, in the choruses, of which the Glee
Club will join, singing in unison. This plan,
which may not seem at first to be a wise one,
has, nevertheless, many good points. In the
first place, the fellows will work harder and
take more interest in the popular songs than
they would if they had to be drilled in parts.
This program can be gotten ready in a shorter
time, which is absolutely necessary this year.
This performance is not to be called a minstrel
show, as several have already termed it, and
it will not cheapen the clubs in any way, as
some few seem to think, as there will be no
"stunts" performed and the jokes will be good,
clean jokes. We expect to hear of several objections to this new plan, but we are prepared
to meet all that could be said against it. It is
well worth trying, and if it is not successful
we shall be able to fall back on the cut and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

dried form of Glee Club performances. We
expect to give at the Baltimore and Washington concerts the regular style of musical clubs'
entertainment. We hope that our new plan
will meet with the approval of all. If everyone comes to the Medical School concert they
will have a chance to criticise the clubs, and
we think that all the criticisms will be favorable.

COTILLON CLUB.
Although the NEws-LETTER thought that
the Board of Governors of the Cotillon Club
was idle, such was not the case, for before the
NEWS-LETTER came out the Board of Governors had held its first meeting and elected
new officers and members. We take pleasure
in announcing the election of \Ir. Richard
Tilghman as President and of M r. Streett as
Secretary and Treasurer. Besides these two
officers just mentioned, the Board of Governors is composed of the following men : M r.
Bird, Mr. Chesney, Mr. Farber, Mr. Houston,
Mr. Hughes, Mr. Lowndes, Mr. Michael, Mr.
Pedrick, Mr. F. J. Smith, Mr. D. Stewart.
It was also decided to limit the number of
the Board to twelve men, as the Board was
getting too large.
At a meeting of the loard last week it was
decided to give only three dances this year,
and to make them really first class, instead
of trying to give four dances which would
would not be so good. We think this is a
very wise plan, and we are already at work
trying to make the dances the best that have
ever been given. The dates for the dances
have been definitely fixed. The first dance
will be on Friday, December 6, which is only
one month off. The other two dances will be
on Friday, January 31, and Friday, April 24.
It is hoped that the dances will be largely attended this season.

This magazine would be greatly improved in

The present one is not suited to a college

The Western. Maryland College Monthly
contains a very good editorial and several
fairly interesting stories. This paper seems to
he well supported by the students.

The Rose said to the Tomb:
"What (lost thou in thy gloom
With the dead soul in thy power?"
The Rose said: "Sombre Tomb,
Of those tears make I in gloom,
Amber perfume, honey-sweet."
Said the 'Comb: "Flower of sorrow,
I send that Soul tomorrow

BALLAD OF THE LADY MARGARET AND HER ROBBER-LOVER.
'T was a cold night of December and the wind was whistling drear,
The robber-band was gathered round the camp-fire flashing clear;
The robber-band was crouching, but their haughty chief stood high,
And he spoke to his fellow bandits—
Ferocious bloody bandits!
His burly, brother bandits under the star-lit sky.
II
"Now is the time to do it"—he raised his arm and said—
'For the young lord's off a'wooing and the old lord's lying dead,
The young lord courts his lady nor knows his father's fall,
And his sister Lady Margaret—
The radiant Lady Margaret—
The matchless, priceless Margaret is alone by her father's pall.

"Now is the time, my comrades, I've woo'd her long in vain,
But soft words now are over—I'll not be scorned again !
With twenty sturdy fellows and this good sword at my side
I'll seize the Lady Margaret—
The fair, disdainful Margaret—
And take my Lady Margaret to be my forest bride,"

•••

•

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

IV.
Around about the fire were twenty men or-more,
And all their faces brightened—they loved adventure sore!
Yes, all the bandits smiled with glee at what their chief had planned,
Save of the number two men—
Of all that number two men
Only were good and true men in all that robber-band.
V.
The first of these had long a grudge against the robber-chief
And long had sworn, when time would serve, he'd cause him mickle grief;
The other was a younger man as unlike as could be,
For he loved the Lady Margaret—
The high, disdainful Margaret—
And none to Lady Margaret was half so true as he.
VI.
So when the robber-band at last had laid them all to rest—
When the plans were now discarded—and the laughter and the jest—
When o'er their heads the moon-light made the night almost as day;
One rose among the sleepers—
Crawled slowly from the sleepers—
Then left behind the sleepers—and spurred his horse away.
VII.
And then a little later, when a cloud came o'er the mcion,
(The moon was paling rapidly, the dawn was coming soon,)
Another figure rose among the sleepers on the ground,
And crept to where his horse stood,
His pride, his gallant horse stood,
The finest horse in camp stood—and still the band slept sound !

VIII.
"Ah, lord, this is no time for love—go not to court to-day,
For thy father lies full stark and still at his castle far away—
Thy sister Margaret weeps nor knows she is in peril sore,
For the robber-bandits come to-night—
Creeping quietly on to-night—
And will take the lady away to-night; she will be seen no more.

X
It was the soft full mid-night—the moon was overhead—
Within the castle banquet hall they watched the noble dead.
And Margaret wept softly when into the castle hall
Clattered her brother the young lord—
Dank with sweat was the young lord,
Grimed with dust was the young lord—and fear came on them all.
XI
Behind him were his archers—"Ye know Our places right,
Get ye at once to the windows—whomever ye see to-night
Creeping, running or walking—turn he his face or his back,
Stop not to think for a moment,
Hesitate not for a moment,
But take good aim for a moment and shoot him down in his track.
•
•
•
XII.
"God grant I may reach her and save her !"—'Twas the robber-lover who prayed,
And his breath came faster and harder, but he stopped not a moment nor staid.
His horse he had left dead behind him—he was nearing the castle wall,
And fifty eyes were before him—
Watching eagerly for him—
Death itself was before him—aimed from the banquet-hall.
XIII.
He came but to warn her of danger—but how were the archers to know?
And they saw him creep in the moon-light in the castle-court below;
A moment they stopped—fifty arrows fleet from their long-bows sped,
And the hero stood but a moment,
Staggered and reeled for a moment,
Then fell in his tracks in a moment—and lay there stark and dead.
XIV.
The lady was saved without him—but in the dark of the earliest morning,
His cold and lifeless body was for the robbers a warning;
For the archers thought, when they slew him, the danger was overpassed.
In life his courage was useless,
His loving courage was useless;
But in death it was not useless—and his story deserves to last!

events, the comparison between the work of
the two British poets will be of interest. Some
year or so ago I was interested in the resemblance between Mr. Phillip's "Nero" and the
anonymous Jacobean play of the same name.
Phillips does not suffer in comparison, though
"Nero" is certainly the poorest of his dramas.
However, it contains much good verse, such as
the description of Poppaza
"Yet hath none fairer strayed into the world,
Nor wandered in more witchery through the air;
Since she who drew the keels of Greece
After her over the Ionian foam."

No pre-Keatsian poet could have written
that. And yet it is not imitation, but an evidence of the poet's natural lineage from the
master.
The Reader—And what a master! Surely,
there is no poem like "The Nightingale" in the

The Critic—No; to use a slang expression,
it and the "Grecian Urn" are in a class by
themselves. There is a white heat of imagination in "The Nightingale."

"Give to the nightingale her shady woods,
A privacy of glorious light is thine!"

Thus Wordsworth addresses the skylark,
and yet the "se f-same song" of the nightingale,
"Found a path
Through the . sad heart of Ruth when, sick for home,
She stood in tears amidst the alien corn,
The same that ofttimes bath

The imagination of this is delicious.
The Reader—But Phillips has almost as
much claim to Tennyson as his master as to
Keats.
The Crtic —Yes; "Marpessa," which is
probably his most widely known poem, does
resemble Tennyson's classic studies, more in
subject and treatment, however, than in actual
form. The priceless "faint Homeric echoes"
are not there. In its places there is verse less

but just as pure.
"Thy voice is like to music heard in birth,
Some spirit lute touched on a spirit sea ;
Thy face remembered is from other worlds,
it has been died for, though T know not when;
It has been sung of, though I know not where,
It has the strangeness of the luring west,
And of sad sea horizons ; beside thee
I am aware of other times and lands,
Of births far back, of lives in many stars,
0 beauty, lone, and like a candle clear
In this dark country of the world!"

The Reader—You quoted a couple of lines
from Wordsworth awhile ago—from the marvelous lines to a skylark. I wish I appreciated
Wordsworth more. I feel as if a certain and
necessary catholicity of taste in matters literary was wanting in me because I find "The
Excursion" very, very dull.
The Critic—I suppose I should be ashamed
of myself, but I fear I agree with you. I love
Wordsworth, but I love him mainly for half
a dozen sonnets and three or four perfect
poems. No less a critic than Matthew Arnold
has said that "Laodamia" and the "Intimations of Immortality" did not represent his
best work. Doubtless, Arnold was right. He
ought to know. But I think they are incomparably his greatest poems. Arnold criticises
a certain artificiality in "Laodamia" and the
declamatory style of the "Immortal Ode," as

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Dr. Furness has called it. Maybe he is
right. Certainly the last verse of the
classic poem — that describing how the
trees withered when they were tall enough to
sec the "topless towers of Ilium"—is artificial,
but in some stanzas, notably two, all trace of
artificiality is lost. I say "notably two." I
mean, of course:
"He spake of love, such love as spirits feel,
In worlds whose course is equable and pure;
No cares to heat away, no strifes to heal,
The past unsighed for and the future sure.
Spake as a witness of a second birth,
For all that is most perfect upon earth.
For all that is most beauteous imagined there
In happier beauty, more pellucid streams
An ampler ether, a diviner air,
And fields invested with purpureal gleams
Climes which the sun who sheds the brightest day
Earth knows, is all unworthy to survey."

As you probably know, the poet altered the
last two lines of the stanzas first quoted to :
"Spake of heroic arts in graver mood,
Revived, with finer harmony pursued."

The alteration is lamentable.
As for the great "Ode," it may tend a trifle
to declamation at times, but at its best it is
glorious.
"Not in entire forgetfulness,
Nor yet in utter nakedness,
But trailing clouds of glory do we come,
From God, who is our home."

The Reader—To go back again, that same
quotation you made from Wordsworth's
"Skylark" reminds me of one of my favorite
poems—Shelly's ode to the same "blithe spirit."
The Critic—Ali, what a genius that man
was!
"In the golden lightning
Of the sunken sun,
O'er which clouds are brightening,
Thou (lost float and run,
Like an unbodied joy whose race has just
begun."

George Meredith has also written a poem on
a Skylark. But, for the wonder of his novels, I
have sometimes thought it were a pity he had
not given his life to poetry. I do not care for
his later verse, but "Love in the Valley," with
its fresh, perfumed morning beauty, is graceful and delicate and worthy of the author of
the two chapters on Richard's early love for
Lucy, in "Feverel":

"She whom I love is hard to catch and conquer;
Hard, but 0 the glory of the winning were she won."

Might not those lines be the guiding motto
of many a man ?
Of a very different sort is "Modern Love."
It has always been too sad, too morbid, for
my taste, save one sonnet only—that of the
momentary reconciliation of husband and wife
by the "twilight wave," under the flight of the
swallows:
"Love, that had robbed us of immortal things,
. This little moment mercifully gave,
And still I see across the twilight wave
The swan sail with her young beneath her wings."

MUSICAL CLUBS.
At the meeting of the Glee Club last week
the leader proposed a new plan, which was accordingly adopted. Although it is something
entirely new for Hopkins, it has been carried
out with great success by several other colleges. Their plan is this: Instead of coming
out in the same old way, first the Glee Club
and then the Mandolin Club, both of the clubs
will be seated on the stage during the entire
performance. There will be an opening
chorus, after which the end men will get off
a few good jokes, and the program will be
continued in more or less the usual manner.
There will be selections by the Mandolin Club
and by the Glee Club. The selections by the
(flee Club will be sung in parts, as usual, but
hesides these there will be several solos of popular songs, in the choruses, of which the Glee
Club will join, singing in unison. This plan,
which may not seem at first to be a wise one,
has, nevertheless, many good points. In the
first place, the fellows will work harder and
take more interest in the popular songs than
they would if they had to be drilled in parts.
This program can be gotten ready in a shorter
time, which is absolutely necessary this year.
This performance is not to be called a minstrel
show, as several have already termed it, and
it will not cheapen the clubs in any way, as
some few seem to think, as there will be no
"stunts" performed and the jokes will be good,
clean jokes. We expect to hear of several objections to this new plan, but we are prepared
to meet all that could be said against it. It is
well worth trying, and if it is not successful
we shall be able to fall back on the cut and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

dried form of Glee Club performances. We
expect to give at the Baltimore and Washington concerts the regular style of musical clubs'
entertainment. We hope that our new plan
will meet with the approval of all. If everyone comes to the Medical School concert they
will have a chance to criticise the clubs, and
we think that all the criticisms will be favorable.

COTILLON CLUB.
Although the NEws-LETTER thought that
the Board of Governors of the Cotillon Club
was idle, such was not the case, for before the
NEWS-LETTER came out the Board of Governors had held its first meeting and elected
new officers and members. We take pleasure
in announcing the election of \Ir. Richard
Tilghman as President and of M r. Streett as
Secretary and Treasurer. Besides these two
officers just mentioned, the Board of Governors is composed of the following men : M r.
Bird, Mr. Chesney, Mr. Farber, Mr. Houston,
Mr. Hughes, Mr. Lowndes, Mr. Michael, Mr.
Pedrick, Mr. F. J. Smith, Mr. D. Stewart.
It was also decided to limit the number of
the Board to twelve men, as the Board was
getting too large.
At a meeting of the loard last week it was
decided to give only three dances this year,
and to make them really first class, instead
of trying to give four dances which would
would not be so good. We think this is a
very wise plan, and we are already at work
trying to make the dances the best that have
ever been given. The dates for the dances
have been definitely fixed. The first dance
will be on Friday, December 6, which is only
one month off. The other two dances will be
on Friday, January 31, and Friday, April 24.
It is hoped that the dances will be largely attended this season.

To the Rose the Tomb said:
"Of the tears the Dawn shed
What makest thou, Love-Flower?"
The Rose said to the Tomb:
"What (lost thou in thy gloom
With the dead soul in thy power?"
The Rose said: "Sombre Tomb,
Of those tears make I in gloom,
Amber perfume, honey-sweet."
Said the 'Comb: "Flower of sorrow,
I send that Soul tomorrow

Mt. Washington was particularly successful
in line plunging, and gained most of its
ground by this means. Rider, at full-back,
was their most consistent ground-gainer. His
terrific plunges through guard and tackle
carried the ball again and again for first down.
Stoneciper punted well. His ball had an
ugly twist that made it hard to handle.
There is one pleasant aspect about the game,
and that is that no one was hurt. Our men
are in fair condition now, and if every one
works his hardest from now to the St. John's
game, there is no reason that we should not
end successfully a season that started unfortunately.
